title: Scientists blame Juul for 2018's 2% rise in young adult vaping
text:
More and more Americans are using e-cigarettes, a new study suggests - and the steepest rises are among the same young adult age group dying of vaping-linked lung illnesses.

According to the new survey analyzed by University of Iowa researchers, about 2.4 percent more 18- to 24-year-olds vaped in 2018 than did in 2017.

Of the 1,300 estimated people who have developed lung illnesses after vaping - a condition now dubbed 'EVALI' - 80 percent are under 35.

Although the new estimates show increases that predate the identification of EVALI, they suggest a worrying trend as Centers for Disease Control and Prevention officials warn that the vaping crisis and the deaths are likely far from over.

And the new study's authors write that the rise in vaping among young adults immediately follows another rise - of Juul to dominate 75 percent of the e-cigarette market in 2017.

Following slow but steady decline in e-cigarette use from 2014 to 2017, Juul reached market dominance and vaping spiked by 2.4% among young adults (gray) in 2018 , a new study found

To quantify trends in vaping in the US, the Iowa team assessed data on over over 153,000 adults over 18 in the US.

They found marginal increases in rates of vaping in all age groups except 45- to 64-year-olds, but only the rise among young adults was deemed 'significant.'

Prior to 2018, the number of people, including young adults, reporting e-cigarette use, was actually on the decline, between 2014 and 2017.

But that trend was turned on its head between 2017 and 2018, the study authors found.

And they point at one specific shift.

'The marketing and sales of e-cigarettes have changed sharply; Juul sales have surged since its introduction in 2015, with the brand capturing the greatest market share by 2017,' they wrote.

'With a discreet design and abundant types of flavors, Juul e-cigarettes are appealing to young people but also concerning because of their high nicotine content.'

By 2017, Juul had cornered three-quarters of the e-cigarette market.

And many health experts and school officials have blamed the easily hidden, USB-like devices and Juul's trendy marketing campaigns for driving teenagers and young adults to start vaping.

To that end, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and Federal Trade Commission (FTC) are both reportedly investigating Juul's marketing and research practices.

Meanwhile, several states, cities and individuals have filed lawsuits against the company, blaming Juul for getting teenagers hooked on its products and draining school resources as they scramble to stem vaping on their campuses.

Additional vaping deaths have now been confirmed in Texas, Utah and Massachusetts, bringing the national toll to 28 fatalities across 23 states (red) in the US

'The trends in young adults are similar to the previously reported trends in current e-cigarette use among US middle and high school students in 2017 and 2018,' wrote the study authors in JAMA Internal Medicine.

'These findings are of public health concern, because nicotine exposure can harm the developing brain, and e-cigarette use may lead to a transition to subsequent cigarette smoking.'

And now vaping poses an additional, deadly danger: EVALI.

At least 28 people have died of vaping-related lung illnesses in recent months in the US.

The youngest was just 17, and the vast majority were under 35.

Most EVALI cases appear to be linked to THC e-cigarettes products, most of which are bootlegged and bought off the street, but the CDC has stressed that nicotine vapes can't be ruled out as a potential cause yet.

It's not clear why most of the fatalities have been among young adults, but the new study's findings suggest it may simply be that this age group is adopting vaping at higher rates than others.
description: After declining rates of vaping between 2014 and 2017, rates rose again among 18- to 24-year-olds - and University of Iowa researcher point to the sleek Juul's rise to market dominance in 2017.
authors: Natalie Rahhal Deputy Health Editor For Dailymail.Com
